captions.text: It’s time for
FOOD ADVENTURE PROGRAM FOR AWESOME PEOPLE
The Chinese Food Edition!
Sooooooooooooo
Its kind of really crappy weather outside?
Really bad
Monsoon season is not in full effect in Korea
Making everyone mopey and
unwilling to leave their houses.
And we’re not going to leave the studio with all our camera gear
So we’re going to be filming some
Inside the studio today.
Yeah, we haven’t been doing a lot of delivery videos
We haven’t even done Korean Chinese food before.
Chinese food in Korea is really really different
From the Chinese food that I grew up with.
Yes.
Ok we’re going to get to ordering now
And I’m feeling a little nervous
Because I’m really nervous whenever
I call on the phone..
Cause no one understands my accent.
I hope it doesn’t go terribly wrong
Na nan a nan a nan a
As soon as I am in a position of pressure
In regards to Korean
My mind farts out
And I can’t remember numbers or
Words and I’ll say the wrong thing
And it’s scary and horrifying.
AHHH
Ok it’s dialing
(KOREAN ORDERING)
Then I’m not going to call them back
Because that was scary! Scary!
Didn’t like it!
Get the gibblies out! Go go go!
I did it!
So our food arrived in funny detail
They gave us like..
Six chopsticks because
“The amount of food they ordered
must be for six people!”
We ordered a lot more
So we could show you
YES! That is why we did that.
We’re not going to eat all this
We did not order this food because we wanted to eat it all
This is way too much for two people to eat
YES IT IS
I could never finish this amount of food.
For science.
If you want to order for yourself
Like one dish
Or you want a special half-and-half
They have special combo versions.
I’m gonna order,
Some jjajangmyun.
NO! no wait! I gonna order some Tang Soo Yook.
Ah! I want both but I can’t eat two servings of each!
What am I gonna do?
Well don’t worry!
With Chinese food Korean delivery,
You can have the best of both worlds!
Really?! How so?!
You can order a half-and-half of each
For the price of one order!
That’s amazing!
Tell me more!
Instead of jampong or jjajjangmyun
You can get jjajjangmyeon!
You can get oojjamyeon! Bokjjamyeon!
Bokjjamyeon! Tangjjamyeon!
And even Tangbokbab!
What do those even mean?
You don’t know stupid??
Then why are even ordering Chinese food?
I just!
Here we go!
Here we go here we go again!
What’s the topic?
Men!
Simon knows the song
So here’s jjajjangmyun
This big fat little blob of noodle here
Not really well separated
Ok so, jjajangmyun is made with like a
Black bean
And I’m pretty sure it’s made with
A lot of like lard as well
So it’s not very healthy
So its not vegetarian friendly
The lard makes it better.
And you know what I feel bad
Because it’s Ramadan now
And a lot of people were saying via Twitter like
Please be considerate of us fasting during Ramadan
Sorryyyy guys. Nope. Sorry.
But it’s very delicious
Really delicious
And if you guys have ever seen Coffee Prince
There’s a scene at the beginning
In the first episode
Where she has a showdown with the dude
And Simon can show you
She takes two bowls to begin with
She mixes it all up
She like makes it into a fist and,
“Look this is my entire meal in one chopstick
but I’m not, I cant eat that all
It’s very, very sticky and filling.
Hey, jjajjangmyun eating race. GO!
What? I don’t want to be throwing.
Right over here we have the
Gochu chapchae.
So this- gochu means pepper,
OR, penis…
Normally we get just chapchae,
And it’s like the noodles
But this is pepper chapchae and this is actually just
No noodles.
I think maybe the pepper replaces the noodle
And it comes with a ggotbang? Like
Flower Boy, its like a flower bun.
And you’re supposed to like put it inside
Its got shrimp, mushrooms, onions
It actually tastes very sesame,
So there’s a very Chinese food taste to it
And this is tang-so-yuk which is like
Supposedly really popular amongst high-school students.
So if you go to a ddokboki restaurant you order this
Which is pork and breaded and deep fried
And they always serve it on the side
It’s like a sweet and sour pineapple sauce
But it’s so thick and syrupy.
Like you can see it dangling there
Ooo, that doesn’t look good.
But it tastes great.
And then we got
For service, which is for free,
Geun-Mandu, which is just like, fried, mandu (dumpling)
And you usually only get friend ones
Consistently at a Chinese food restaurant
Most Korean places do steamed.
And we also got for service little spring rolls
Which are so-so
But I haven’t had spring rolls in a long time
So I’m not gonna
Complain about it.
And of course there is the jjajjangmyun.
Before we eat all this,
How about some sexy food porn shots.
OOOOoooooOOOooOooOoo.
I don’t know how sexy this can be.
Oh, God its so good, just.
That was a bad idea.
Interesting jjajjangyun facts!
Jjajjangmyun is kinda like the bachelor food of Korea
So if you’re a dude and you’re living by yourself
You will probably be ordering jjajjangmyun a lot
This is the equivalent of macaroni and cheese for college students
So you know the whole culture of like
Valentine’s Day and then White Day
We did a couple of videos before
But the month after white day,
There’s black day.
For single people!
Who don’t have any special person to love.
And what they usually do on black day
Is eat jjajjangmyun.
People will get together
To eat jjajangmyun together, in sadness.
So there’s like a big group of people all single,
Eating it together.
With a big pile of tissues in the middle so they can all cry.
Or they can meet each other, and no
Longer be apart of Black Day.
Third interesting jjajjangmyun fact!
When people move into a new house,
They traditionally order jjajangmyun
I don’t know if that’s supposed to be
Something that’s supposed to be passed down in Korea,
Or if it’s just really easy to eat
And you don’t need anything much but a chopstick
But that seems to be a thing to do
And I’ve even seen it in the We Got Married dramas,
Where they move in and they eat jjajangmyun.
Fourth interesting fact!
This is supposed to be Chinese food!
Oh right!
But I’ve never actually had anything like this in Canada
For any of the Chinese food that I had
And any of the Chinese food that I had in Canada,
I can’t find here in Korea.
Listen! Toronto has an entire china town
Where Chinese people who only speak Chinese
Who make Chinese food, with Chinese restaurants,
It is legit Chinese food,
And this does not exist.
AND,
Our friend that lived in China said that,
This is not in china!
So Chinese food in Korea is really like,
Korean-fusion takes on Chinese food.
Chinese people who have come to Korean and had jjajjanmyun!
I want your opinion on this!
Can you get this meal in china or not?
And you can’t even answer that because
You’re in china and you can’t watch YouTube.
NA Nan a nan a nan a. You can’t watch the You Tubes!
This is not very good date food by the way you guys.
Unless your idea of a date is
Getting covered in grease
And not getting any napkins.
Korean deliveries provide everything for you,
Except for napkins.
Um, why didn’t you get me a napkin?
I didn’t know that you needed any
Look at me!
Oh! Sick! AH GAHD! Gross!
So that’s it for this week’s
Food adventure program for awesome people
I am unnaturally stuffed and I am going to go take
A four-hour nap.
I barely ate any of mine because
I’m not a piggy!
I’m going to sleep.
Simon, is a due-ji (piggy)
Hey Leigh, do you hear me?
Do you want some food Leigh?
Do you want some of my jjajjangmyun or …
Oh…..
Do you want some of mine?
Do you want some of this?
Do you want the last gun-mandu?
What if I eat it?
What if I eat all of it?
Ok.
These are the best part about ordering delivery in Korea.
You don’t have to clean anything up, you just dump it
All in the bag that they provide for you
And you leave it on the stairwell.
Pretty cool right?
Finished! Freedom.
undefined

comments.author: cara rose

comments.text:
About the Jjajang Myoen. In the north part of China it is a big deal 
especially during summers. The sauce is lighter coloured than its Korean 
counterpart, with more pork in the sauce and more toppings to mix into the 
noodle. Chinese Jjajang Myoen is spelled Zhajiang Mian in Pinyin. Vice 
president Biden had Zhajiang Mian during his visit in Beijing.﻿
comments.author: Ruozhuo Li

comments.text:
The way I see about people eating 짜장면 when they are moving is because they 
do not fully have all the kitchen equips settled + 짜장면 is one of the most 
common delivery food (you can basically get it from almost anywhere) while 
such things like fried chicken maybe too dirty to eat (you either grab a 
fork: not possible since your kitchen equips are probably still packed, or 
with hand which requires you to wash your hand = not generally a thing that 
you would do). Also, you do not have to do anything for clean up. After you 
are done, you throw away left overs in a garbage bag and leave the plates 
(usually cover them with newspaper sheet) at the outside.﻿
comments.author: David Lee

In fact, Zhajiangmian is a traditional Chinese (Beijing) food. May be your

comments.author: Weixi Wang

comments.text:
The dish is called zha-jiang-mian in Chinese; it's a traditional Peking 
dish so it's not surprising that Simon never saw it in Canton (which is the 
south). For anyone who has Chinese friends or lived in china should have 
known better that each region has their own food and, even in China, it's 
kinda common for a Chinese to never heard of a certain Chinese dish (like 
most chinese will tell you they have no idea what orange chicken is even 
though it's a legit dish in China, just not popular)
Korean jjajangmyun is darker, sweeter and thicker, the sauce has more 
ingredients than the Chinese version. Chinese zhajiangmian is lighter, 
usually the sauce is only made of ground pork and soysauce paste. To me 
these two dishes taste entirely different, both taste good, personally like 
chinese ver better﻿

comments.author: MarkCEO09

comments.text:
http://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zhajiangmian
For ur two, information. zhajiangmian also in mandarin 炸酱面 is a Beijing 
local food. Pretty much only ppl who lived around Beijing area or close 
provinces eat it. And also with the noodle u have a lot fresh boiled veggie 
toppings on it. Like shredded boiled wombok, fresh boiled soya bean, 
shredded cucumber or turnip.

The zhajiang'mian usually use fermented soya bean paste fried with diced 
pork and onion with plenty oil. Which makes it very salty. Korean versions 
of zhajiangmian is sweet. Similar to the news version of zhajiangmian in 
China, some place use hoisin sauce. ﻿

comments.author: Hanajumy Sayako

comments.text:
Zhajiangmian is "Bei Pai" (North style) noodle; what people have in Toronto 
is usually "Nan Pai" (South style) noodle. And even if you are in a Toronto 
north style Chinese restaurant, you can't find Zhajiangmian b/c it is being 
considered as a low-en-homemade-fast food, it will not be served in a 
restaurant. This is so understandable once people try to introduce their 
food to a new culture, usually the easiest and the simplest food is mostly 
ideal to be accepted. And that's why you can see Pho and hamburgers spread 
a lot in the world.﻿

comments.text:
I'm Korean and this is my Dad's favorite food. My roommate was Chinese and 
one day I went hunting for this in San Diego and told him about it, he 
immediately told my this was Chinese food. So yes, after a little research 
and conversation I learned this originated in China, although not hugely 
popular. You have to eat it with the red pepper flakes gochu galoo and 
vinegar and also eat it with the yellow moo to cut through the greasy 
factor it will make a world of difference.﻿

comments.author: Lin Li

comments.text:
I'm Chinese studying in US. I had Jiajang Myeon in Seoul. (Sorry if spelled 
wrong) Actually Jiajang M is a very popular noodle dish in Northern China, 
esp in Beijing. It's written as 炸酱面 in Chinese. I would say the Korean 
version has less minced meat and a sweeter taste than what I had in China. 
The other two dishes are 炒杂菜 and 糖醋肉, less popular in China.﻿
comments.author: Lin Li

comments.text: Jajienmein is a Chinese food but Korean people changed it a lot﻿
comments.author: Cherie Chan

comments.text:
from my knowledge, all I know is that a long time ago Chinese immigrants in 
Korea made this dish because they were missing traditional Chinese food. 
The noodles were cheap and since they weren't very well paid back then, 
they made the sauce with whatever they had, which was the black bean sauce.﻿
comments.author: Sapphire Maple Hayden

comments.text: Korea does Chinese food soooooooo much better than America ﻿

I'm Chinese, and my mom used to cook jiajangmyun for me all the time.But I

restaurant in the States, maybe because this dish is meant to be cooked at

Korean name.﻿

comments.text:
+Nataly Gómez Tamotsu- Kun is right, though I've only experienced that in 
China. You're supposed to leave one bite of food on your plate to honour 
the host. It shows that he/she has done their job and provided enough food 
for all the guests. Just a heads up if you wanna visit China ;)

But throwing such a large amount of food... that isn't done *tries to stop 
cringing* As a student it makes me want to smack my head against a wall and 
end my suffering ."
comments.author: The Nomadic Wallfower

comments.text:
The Chinese food in North American Chinatowns are mainly Cantonese cuisine 
which is in southern China. Jjajangmyeon is from the Northern provinces 
which are much closer to Korea. The early Chinese immigrants to Korea were

comments.text:
As far as I know Chinese 'zhajiangmian' made of salty fermented wheat flour 
sauce, fried meats, chopped leeks, coriander, pure wheat flour noodle to 
dry and cool. 'Jajangmyun' is made by 'Wang song san' open restaurant 'Gong 
wha choon' in Korea at 1948 years. He were migrated overseas Chinese from 
China. He uses wheat flour, beans flour, caramel made called 'Choon jang' 
sauce. After he use 'Choon jang' sauce, vegetables, baking powder mixed 
many times kneaded chewy noodles to wet and warm and made 'Jajangmyun' suit 
Korean people's palate. since that many time spend, fork meat, egg, onions, 
potato starch added and current 'Jajangmyun' is completed.﻿
